My forecast is based on a high recent base rate of coups, primarily in Africa, tempered by the very short timeframe of just over two months. 

Analysis of Base Rate: The background information highlights a significant 'coup belt' in Africa's Sahel region, with at least seven successful coups since 2020 (Mali x2, Guinea, Burkina Faso x2, Niger, Gabon). This establishes an annual rate of well over one successful coup per year in Africa alone. In contrast, recent coup attempts in Latin America (Peru, Brazil, Bolivia) have been unsuccessful, suggesting a lower probability of a successful event in that region, though the risk is not zero. 

Key Regional Factors: The underlying drivers of coups in the Sahel—persistent insecurity from jihadist insurgencies, poor governance, economic hardship, and geopolitical shifts—remain firmly in place, creating a persistently volatile environment where further takeovers are plausible. In Latin America, the research assistant's report of high tensions in Venezuela following a disputed election presents the most likely, though still improbable, path to a 'Yes' outcome, likely through a self-coup as defined by the resolution criteria.

Why not higher than 30%? The primary constraint is the very short time window. Coups are major political ruptures that, while frequent in some regions on a multi-year timescale, are still rare events on any given day. A period of just over two months significantly lowers the probability of such an event occurring compared to a full year.

Why not lower than 30%? Ignoring the high demonstrated frequency of coups in the Sahel would be a mistake. The conditions are ripe, and the pattern of 'coup contagion' in the region has been clearly established. A probability below 20% would understate the fragility of several governments in West and Central Africa.

I would increase my forecast upon receiving credible reports of unusual military deployments in a capital city, the arrest of a head of state, or a clear move by an incumbent to unconstitutionally retain power. I would decrease my forecast as the deadline approaches without such incidents, or if there is a significant de-escalation of a major political crisis in a high-risk country.

A coup d’état (often shortened to "coup") is [defined](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Coup_d'%C3%A9tat) as an event in which a state's military or other components of its power structure overthrow the existing political authority. 

A "successful" coup is defined as a coup in which the group or person attempting to seize power establishes control over both the government and military, and will be considered to have succeeded once any significant resistance to their authority has ceased. 

A self-coup, [defined](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Self-coup) as a political leader, having come to power through legal means, remaining in power through illegal means, will count. This includes scenarios in which an incumbent leader refuses to relinquish power after an election.

External support for a coup, such as is described [here](https://africacenter.org/spotlight/africas-coups-and-the-role-of-external-actors/), will count as long as the mercenaries or other external actors are acting in support of a perpetrator from within the state.

Civil wars, mutinies, rebellions or popular uprisings will not count, nor will changes to a country's constitution that restrict a country's democratic norms.
